dict.string: Opens in incognito, and closes the original tab
Opens in window with new profile
Opens in window with new profile, and closes the original tab
Opens Chrome’s frontmost tab in an incognito window
Opens Chrome’s frontmost tab in an incognito window
tell application "Google Chrome" set theURL to URL of active tab of front window make new window with properties {mode:"incognito"} tell active tab of front window to set URL to theURL end tell

tell application "Google Chrome" set theURL to URL of active tab of front window close active tab of front window make new window with properties {mode:"incognito"} tell active tab of front window to set URL to theURL end tell

tell application "Google Chrome" set theURL to URL of active tab of front window end tell do shell script "open --new -a \"Google Chrome\" --args --user-data-dir=\"/tmp/incognitoclone-$RANDOM\" --no-first-run " & theURL

tell application "Google Chrome" set theURL to URL of active tab of front window close active tab of front window end tell
do shell script "open --new -a \"Google Chrome\" --args --user-data-dir=\"/tmp/incognitoclone-$RANDOM\" --no-first-run " & theURL

Quickly open your current Chrome tab in incognito mode or a new Chrome instance with an empty profile — the latter means it’ll act just as if you hadn’t changed a single setting, which is particularly useful when something you changed (like preventing plugins from loading) is making it difficult to use a page.
Call it with `ic`, and it will open a new incognito window with your current tab. ⌘↩ will also close the tab in your current window. ⌥↩ to open the current tab in a new Chrome instance, and ⌃↩ to also close the tab in the current window.
